title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Corinthians chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Corinthians Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is the apostle mentioned in 2 Corinthians 1:1?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:1 states that Paul is an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God.

questions.question: To whom is the letter in 2 Corinthians 1:1 addressed?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:1 clearly addresses the church of God which is at Corinth.

questions.question: What greeting does Paul send in 2 Corinthians 1:2?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:2 says, 'Grace be to you and peace from God our Father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ.'

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:3, God is the Father of what?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:3 calls God the Father of mercies and the God of all comfort.

questions.question: What does God provide us in all our tribulation according to 2 Corinthians 1:4?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:4 states that God comforts us in all our tribulation.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 1:5 says that our consolation abounds by Christ as the sufferings of Christ abound in us.
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:5 explains that as the sufferings of Christ abound in us, so does our consolation by Christ.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:7, what is the hope of Paul regarding the Corinthians?
options: They will share in sufferings and consolation
They will be free from suffering
questions.correctAnswer: They will share in sufferings and consolation
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:7 states that the hope is that as they share in sufferings, they will also share in consolation.

questions.question: Where did Paul experience trouble as mentioned in 2 Corinthians 1:8?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:8 says Paul and his companions had trouble in Asia.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Corinthians 1:9: 'But we had the sentence of death in ourselves, that we should not trust in ______, but in God which raiseth the dead:'
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:9 says we should not trust in ourselves but in God who raises the dead.

questions.question: Who does Paul say delivered them from great death in 2 Corinthians 1:10?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:10 states that God delivered them from so great a death and is trusted to deliver again.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:11, how do the Corinthians help Paul and his companions?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:11 says the Corinthians help together by prayer for Paul and his companions.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 1:12 says Paul and his companions used fleshly wisdom in their conduct.
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:12 states they did not use fleshly wisdom but the grace of God in their conduct.

questions.question: Who preached Jesus Christ among the Corinthians according to 2 Corinthians 1:19?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:19 says Jesus Christ was preached among the Corinthians by Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:21, who establishes us with you in Christ and anoints us?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:21 states that God establishes and anoints us with you in Christ.

questions.question: True or False: In 2 Corinthians 1:24, Paul claims dominion over the faith of the Corinthians.
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:24 says Paul does not have dominion over their faith but are helpers of their joy.

medium.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Corinthians Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 2 Corinthians 1, what biblical truth would you share about God's comfort?
options: God comforts us in all troubles so we can comfort others.
God abandons us when we suffer.
God's comfort is only for future rewards.
questions.correctAnswer: God comforts us in all troubles so we can comfort others.
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:3-4 teaches that God is the Father of mercies and the God of all comfort, who comforts us in all our tribulation so that we can comfort others with the same comfort we have received.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 1 instruct believers to respond when facing suffering?
options: Trust in God who raises the dead and deliver us.
Depend solely on their own strength.
Ignore suffering and focus on earthly pleasures.
Quit their faith if suffering becomes too great.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God who raises the dead and deliver us.
questions.explanation: Verse 9 emphasizes that Paul and his companions did not rely on themselves but on God who raises the dead, showing that trust in God is essential when enduring suffering.

questions.question: What role does prayer play according to 2 Corinthians 1 for those enduring difficulties?
options: Prayer helps others by supporting one another.
Prayer only benefits the person praying.
Prayer should be avoided to focus on action.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer helps others by supporting one another.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 encourages believers to help together by prayer so that thanks may be given by many on behalf of those undergoing trials, highlighting the power of communal prayer.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1, what is the attitude Paul claims to have had in his conduct toward the Corinthians?
options: Simplicity and godly sincerity, not fleshly wisdom.
Cunning and worldly wisdom to persuade.
Harshness and severity to control them.
questions.correctAnswer: Simplicity and godly sincerity, not fleshly wisdom.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states that Paul’s rejoicing is the testimony of his conscience, that in simplicity and godly sincerity, not with fleshly wisdom, he conducted himself before God and the Corinthians.

questions.question: In the context of 2 Corinthians 1, how should believers view suffering in relation to salvation?
options: Suffering can produce consolation and salvation for others.
Suffering is meaningless and should be avoided at all costs.
questions.correctAnswer: Suffering can produce consolation and salvation for others.
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 explain that Paul’s afflictions are for the Corinthians’ consolation and salvation, showing that suffering can have a purpose beyond personal hardship.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 1 say about the promises of God in Jesus Christ?
options: All the promises of God are 'Yes' and 'Amen' in Christ.
The promises of God are uncertain and conditional.
God’s promises depend on human effort alone.
Promises are only for the future, not the present.
questions.correctAnswer: All the promises of God are 'Yes' and 'Amen' in Christ.
questions.explanation: Verse 20 clearly states that all God’s promises find their 'Yes' and 'Amen' in Jesus Christ, affirming the certainty and fulfillment of God’s promises.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the role of God in the believers' lives according to 2 Corinthians 1?
options: God establishes and anoints believers, sealing them with the Spirit.
God leaves believers to their own devices.
God only watches from a distance.
God punishes believers for their failures.
questions.correctAnswer: God establishes and anoints believers, sealing them with the Spirit.
questions.explanation: Verses 21-22 reveal that God establishes believers in Christ, anoints them, seals them, and gives the Spirit as a guarantee in their hearts.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 1, Paul asserts that he has dominion over the Corinthians' faith.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 states Paul and his co-workers do not have dominion over the Corinthians' faith but are helpers of their joy, emphasizing humility and support rather than control.

questions.question: True or False: Paul’s intention to visit the Corinthians was made lightly and without serious purpose according to 2 Corinthians 1.
questions.explanation: In verses 17-18, Paul clarifies that his plans were not made lightly or according to the flesh, but with sincerity and truthfulness, not being 'yes and no' but consistent.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 2 Corinthians 1:2, grace and peace come from God our Father and from the _____ Jesus Christ.
questions.explanation: Verse 2 clearly states that grace and peace come from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ, emphasizing the divine source of blessings.

questions.question: Based on 2 Corinthians 1, what motivates Paul to share his hardships with the Corinthians?
options: To make them aware so they can find consolation and salvation.
questions.correctAnswer: To make them aware so they can find consolation and salvation.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 explains Paul’s desire not to have the Corinthians be ignorant of his troubles, which serve to encourage their consolation and salvation through shared suffering.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the relationship between his sufferings and the Corinthians' participation in 2 Corinthians 1?
options: As they share in sufferings, they also share in consolation.
They suffer alone without any consolation.
Only Paul suffers, the Corinthians are exempt.
questions.correctAnswer: As they share in sufferings, they also share in consolation.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 indicates that the hope of Paul is steadfast because as the Corinthians share in sufferings, they will also share in the consolation, linking mutual participation in trials and encouragement.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1, what is the purpose of Paul’s delayed visit to the Corinthians?
options: To spare them and not cause unnecessary distress.
Because he lost interest in visiting.
To avoid them due to conflict.
Because he was uncertain about his plans.
questions.correctAnswer: To spare them and not cause unnecessary distress.
questions.explanation: Verse 23 states that Paul calls God to witness that he delayed his visit to spare the Corinthians, showing his concern for their wellbeing.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 1 teach about honesty and integrity in communication?
options: Paul’s word toward the Corinthians is not 'yes and no' but is truthful and consistent.
Changing one’s word for convenience is acceptable.
Ambiguity is preferred to maintain peace.
Silence is better than honest communication.
questions.correctAnswer: Paul’s word toward the Corinthians is not 'yes and no' but is truthful and consistent.
questions.explanation: Verses 17-18 emphasize that Paul’s intentions and promises were not made lightly or inconsistently but were truthful, reflecting integrity in his communication.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 1 encourage believers to view their role in the faith community?
options: As helpers of others’ joy, not as dominators of faith.
As indifferent to others’ spiritual growth.
questions.correctAnswer: As helpers of others’ joy, not as dominators of faith.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 teaches that Paul and his co-workers do not have dominion over the Corinthians' faith but serve as helpers of their joy, promoting mutual support over control.

hard.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Corinthians Chapter 1.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 1:3, God is called the Father of mercies and the God of all comfort. Which Old Testament attribute of God does this title most closely reflect?
options: God as a refuge and strength in Psalm 46
God as a consuming fire in Deuteronomy 4
God as a jealous God in Exodus 20
God as a God of judgment in Isaiah 33
questions.correctAnswer: God as a refuge and strength in Psalm 46
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:3 describes God as the Father of mercies and comfort, which parallels the Psalmist's depiction of God as a refuge and strength who provides comfort in times of trouble (Psalm 46).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:4, what is the purpose of the comfort God gives us in our tribulations?
options: So that we may comfort others in trouble
So that we may avoid all suffering
So that we may gain earthly riches
So that we may prove our strength
questions.correctAnswer: So that we may comfort others in trouble
questions.explanation: Verse 4 clearly states that God comforts us in our tribulations so that we may be able to comfort those who are in any trouble with the comfort we receive from God.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 1:5, Paul writes 'as the sufferings of Christ abound in us, so our consolation also aboundeth by Christ.' Which New Testament theological concept does this reflect?
options: Participation in Christ's sufferings and comfort
questions.correctAnswer: Participation in Christ's sufferings and comfort
questions.explanation: This verse reflects the Pauline theology of believers sharing in Christ’s sufferings and correspondingly sharing in the consolation that Christ provides, a key theme in Pauline letters (cf. Romans 8:17).

questions.question: 2 Corinthians 1:8 describes Paul’s trouble in Asia as being 'pressed out of measure, above strength.' What Old Testament figure’s experience does this most closely resemble?
questions.explanation: Paul’s description of being overwhelmed and despairing even of life closely parallels Job’s intense suffering and endurance under great tribulation in the Old Testament.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 1:9, Paul says, 'we had the sentence of death in ourselves, that we should not trust in ourselves, but in God who raises the dead.' Which theological theme is most prominent here?
options: Human merit as the basis of salvation
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes that in the face of death, trust must be placed not in human strength but in God’s power to raise the dead, foreshadowing the resurrection hope central to Christian faith.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:11, how do the Corinthians assist Paul and his companions?
options: By preaching the gospel with them
By writing letters to the churches
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states that the Corinthians help Paul and others by joining together in prayer, which supports their ministry and leads to thanksgiving on their behalf.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 1:12, Paul contrasts 'simplicity and godly sincerity' with what other quality in his conduct?
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts his godly sincerity and simplicity with 'fleshly wisdom,' emphasizing that his conduct is guided by God's grace rather than human cunning.

questions.question: 2 Corinthians 1:18 says, 'as God is true, our word toward you was not yea and nay.' What figure of speech is Paul employing here?
questions.explanation: Paul uses antithesis by contrasting 'yea and nay' to emphasize the consistency and reliability of his word, reflecting God's truthfulness.

questions.question: In verse 19, Paul refers to Jesus Christ as 'not yea and nay, but in him was yea.' Which Old Testament covenantal concept does this affirm?
options: The conditionality of the Mosaic Law
questions.explanation: The phrase emphasizes the certainty and unchangeableness of God's promises fulfilled in Christ, echoing covenant themes of divine faithfulness in the Old Testament.

questions.question: 2 Corinthians 1:20 says, 'For all the promises of God in him are yea, and in him Amen.' The word 'Amen' here most directly signifies:
questions.explanation: 'Amen' is a Hebrew term meaning 'so be it' or 'truly,' signifying affirmation and certainty that God's promises in Christ are trustworthy.

questions.question: Who, according to 2 Corinthians 1:22, has sealed the believers and given the earnest of the Spirit in their hearts?
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states that God has sealed believers and given the earnest (pledge) of the Holy Spirit in their hearts, signifying divine ownership and guarantee of inheritance.

questions.question: 2 Corinthians 1:24 mentions that Paul and his companions are 'helpers of your joy' and not having dominion over your faith. What does this reveal about Paul's apostolic approach?
options: He respects the believers' faith autonomy
He demands strict obedience and control
questions.correctAnswer: He respects the believers' faith autonomy
questions.explanation: Paul clarifies that he does not exercise authoritarian control over the Corinthians’ faith but instead assists and encourages their joy and growth in faith.

questions.question: In the context of 2 Corinthians 1:23, what was Paul's reason for not visiting Corinth earlier?
questions.explanation: Paul calls God as witness that his delay in visiting Corinth was intentional to spare them, indicating pastoral concern and careful timing.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 1:7, Paul has a steadfast hope that the Corinthians will partake only in the consolation and not the sufferings.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that the Corinthians are partakers of the sufferings as well as the consolation, showing that both experiences are shared among believers.

questions.question: True or False: In 2 Corinthians 1:17, Paul asserts that he made his plans lightly and according to the flesh, leading to inconsistency in his word.
questions.explanation: Paul denies using lightness or fleshly purposes, affirming that his plans are consistent and trustworthy, not marked by 'yea and nay' (verse 17).

theological.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Corinthians Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:3, which three titles are ascribed to God the Father?
options: Father of mercies, God of all comfort, and Creator of heaven and earth
Father of mercies, God of all comfort, and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ
Father of lights, God of all knowledge, and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ
Father of mercies, God of all power, and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Father of mercies, God of all comfort, and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:3 identifies God as the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies, and the God of all comfort, highlighting His merciful and comforting nature. This aligns with Exodus 34:6 (merciful and gracious God), Isaiah 40:1 (comforting the afflicted), and Romans 15:5 (God of patience and comfort).

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of God's comfort in believers according to 2 Corinthians 1:4?
options: To enable believers to comfort others in trouble
questions.correctAnswer: To enable believers to comfort others in trouble
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 1:4 teaches that God comforts us in all tribulation so that we may comfort others who are in any trouble, reflecting the biblical call to mutual encouragement (Romans 12:15, Galatians 6:2, 1 Thessalonians 5:11).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:5, how do the sufferings of Christ relate to believers?
options: Believers experience the sufferings of Christ, and consolation abounds through Him
Believers suffer only because of their own sins
Believers are exempt from suffering due to Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Believers experience the sufferings of Christ, and consolation abounds through Him
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that as the sufferings of Christ abound in us, so our consolation also abounds by Christ, emphasizing the participatory nature of suffering and comfort (Philippians 3:10, Romans 8:17, 1 Peter 4:13).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give in 2 Corinthians 1:9 for not trusting in himself?
options: Because he was sentenced to death in himself and must trust in God who raises the dead
Because he was not chosen by God
questions.correctAnswer: Because he was sentenced to death in himself and must trust in God who raises the dead
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 1:9, Paul explains that experiencing a sentence of death led him to rely not on himself but on God who raises the dead, underscoring human dependence on divine power (Psalm 146:8, Ezekiel 37:1–14, Romans 8:11, John 11:25).

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 1:11, what role do believers play in Paul's deliverance?
options: They help by praying for him
questions.correctAnswer: They help by praying for him
questions.explanation: Verse 11 emphasizes the believers' cooperation in prayer, which is instrumental in Paul's deliverance, highlighting the biblical principle of intercessory prayer (Ephesians 6:18, James 5:16, Colossians 4:12, Hebrews 13:18).

questions.question: How does Paul describe his conduct among the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 1:12?
options: With simplicity and godly sincerity by the grace of God
questions.correctAnswer: With simplicity and godly sincerity by the grace of God
questions.explanation: Paul states that his conduct was marked by simplicity and godly sincerity, not fleshly wisdom, but by God's grace, reflecting Christian integrity (Philippians 1:27, Colossians 3:22, 1 Timothy 1:5, Titus 2:7).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:18, how does Paul affirm the certainty of his word to the Corinthians?
options: His word was like yea and nay
His word was not yea and nay, because God is true
His word was based on human opinion
questions.correctAnswer: His word was not yea and nay, because God is true
questions.explanation: Paul asserts that his word was steadfast and reliable because God is true, affirming the divine faithfulness behind apostolic teaching (Numbers 23:19, Hebrews 6:18, Titus 1:2, Psalm 33:4).

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 1:20, what is said about the promises of God in Christ?
options: They are yea and amen in Him
They are conditional upon human works
questions.correctAnswer: They are yea and amen in Him
questions.explanation: Verse 20 states that all the promises of God find their yes and amen in Christ, meaning they are fully confirmed and guaranteed in Him, consistent with scriptures like 2 Samuel 7:28, Isaiah 55:11, Hebrews 10:23, and John 6:37.

questions.question: Who is described in 2 Corinthians 1:22 as having sealed believers and given the earnest of the Spirit in their hearts?
questions.explanation: Verse 22 identifies God as the one who seals believers and gives the earnest (down payment) of the Holy Spirit in their hearts, reflecting the doctrine of the Spirit as a guarantee of salvation (Ephesians 1:13-14, Romans 8:16, John 14:16-17, 2 Timothy 1:14).

questions.question: What does Paul state as the reason he had not yet come to Corinth in 2 Corinthians 1:23?
options: He was afraid of the Jews
He was busy with other churches
questions.explanation: Paul calls God to witness that he had refrained from coming to Corinth so as to spare them, showing pastoral sensitivity (Acts 20:31, 1 Thessalonians 2:7, Galatians 4:13, Romans 15:1).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:24, what is the role of Paul and his coworkers in relation to the Corinthians' faith?
options: They have dominion over their faith
They are helpers of their joy
They are indifferent to their faith
questions.correctAnswer: They are helpers of their joy
questions.explanation: Paul clarifies that he and his coworkers do not have dominion over the Corinthians' faith but serve as helpers of their joy, emphasizing servant leadership and encouragement (Philippians 2:25, 1 Thessalonians 2:19, Galatians 4:19, Romans 12:8).

questions.question: What does Paul mean in 2 Corinthians 1:7 by saying "our hope of you is stedfast"?
options: He has unwavering confidence that they share in sufferings and consolation
He hopes they will be more generous
He expects them to be perfect
questions.correctAnswer: He has unwavering confidence that they share in sufferings and consolation
questions.explanation: Paul expresses firm hope that as the Corinthians share in the sufferings, so they will also share in the consolation, reflecting mutual participation in the Christian journey (Romans 5:3-5, Hebrews 6:19, 1 Peter 1:13, Philippians 1:6).

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 1:8 reveal about Paul's experience in Asia?
options: He was pressed beyond strength and despaired even of life
He was ignored by the believers
questions.correctAnswer: He was pressed beyond strength and despaired even of life
questions.explanation: Paul describes intense suffering and despair that overcame him in Asia, underscoring the reality of apostolic suffering (Acts 20:22-24, 2 Timothy 3:12, Philippians 1:29, Hebrews 11:25).

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 1:21, who is said to establish and anoint the believers with Paul and the Corinthians?
questions.explanation: Verse 21 states that God establishes believers with Paul and the Corinthians and anoints them, affirming God's sovereign role in sanctification and ministry (Psalm 89:20, Isaiah 61:1, Luke 4:18, 1 John 2:20).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 1:13, what does Paul say about the content of his letters to the Corinthians?
options: He writes new doctrines not acknowledged by them
He writes what they read and acknowledge, trusting they will acknowledge to the end
He writes only about financial matters
questions.correctAnswer: He writes what they read and acknowledge, trusting they will acknowledge to the end
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes that his letters contain teachings the Corinthians already read and acknowledge, expecting their continued acceptance, highlighting apostolic consistency (Galatians 1:8, 1 Corinthians 14:37, 2 Timothy 3:16, Acts 17:11).
